column6: Directed independent study for freshmen in any department.
Required of all honors freshmen in lieu of College Writing. Stresses exploration, discussion and communication of ideas expressed in works related to theme of colloquium.
Continuation of HONR 10197.
(Equivalent to HIST 11050) World history from early human societies through the mid-17th century.

column2: COLLOQUIUM: THE HISTORY OF CIVILIZATION II
column6: (Equivalent to HIST 11051) Continuation of HONR 13197. World history from mid 17th century to the present.
(Equivalent to HIST 12070) Survey of U.S. history through 1877.
(Equivalent to HIST 12071) Survey of U.S. history since 1877.

column4: admitted to the Honors College and special approval.
column6: Focuses on Western and non-Western cultures from a comparative perspective, in order to identify both different and shared values and to see how one's own culture shapes one's perspective, ideology, and values.

(Equivalent to POL 10100) This course covers the basic elements of politics at the national level in the United States: structures, processes, behaviors, institutions and policies. Special emphasis is given to conflicting theories of power as they apply to different economic, sexual and racial groups in America.

(Equivalent to POL 10500) A practical, theoretical introduction to a study of systematic patterns in international relations. Includes analysis of rules, instruments, processes, decision- making factors, conflict resolution.

(Equivalent to POL 10004) This course introduces the different institutional structures of governance (e.g., parliamentary versus presidential systems) in a range of different states; for different types of regimes (e.g. democratic and authoritarian); and at the international level.
Directed independent study for sophomores in any department.
One-semester course or two-semester sequence exploring interdisciplinary ideas and issues related to a single theme, by means of readings, discussion and individual papers and projects.
See HONR 20197.

(Equivalent to ECON 22060) Principles and policies affecting prices, including factor incomes, under alternative market structures. Tools developed to examine social problems, including poverty, crime, pollution and international relations.

column4: Admitted to the Honors College; and HONR 21197 or ECON 22060.
column6: (Equivalent to ECON 22061) Principles and policies affecting aggregate production, consumption, investment and government expenditures. Includes role of money, the banking system, inflation, unemployment and economic growth.
Directed independent study for juniors in any department.

One-semester course or two-semester sequence for juniors or seniors exploring interdisciplinary ideas and issues related to single theme, by means of readings, discussion and individual papers and projects.
See HONR 30197.
Designed for students preparing for participation in overseas programs sponsored by the Office of International Affairs. Provides basis for future research abroad.
Intensive study of significant problems in politics. Topic readings and core research theme vary from semester to semester.
Construction of a senior portfolio, consisting of a collection of artifacts and a reflective essay interpreting the student's growth during the college years.

column4: Prior special approval of instructor and special approval of and preregistration with Honors College.
column6: Directed independent study for seniors in any department.
Thesis or creative project.
One-semester course or two-semester sequence exploring interdisciplinary ideas and issues related to single theme, by means of readings, discussion and individual papers and projects.
